quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 10 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 10.6: Standard Reduction Potentials and EMF Series
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: What are the standard conditions for measuring standard reduction potentials ($E^\circ$)?
questions.explanation: Standard states in electrochemistry are defined as 298.15 K, 1.0 M for aqueous species, and 1.0 atm for gases.

questions.question: A substance with a very high, positive $E^\circ$ value is a ________.
questions.explanation: A high positive reduction potential means the substance is easily reduced. Since it is easily reduced, it is very effective at oxidizing other substances.

questions.question: The standard reduction potential of the Standard Hydrogen Electrode (SHE) is exactly:
questions.explanation: The SHE serves as the universal reference point from which all other potentials are measured and is assigned a value of zero by convention.

questions.question: If two half-cells are connected, the one with the **more positive** reduction potential will undergo:
questions.explanation: The species with the greater 'pull' for electrons (higher $E^\circ$) will always win the tug-of-war and be reduced at the cathode.

questions.question: Fluorine ($F_2$) has one of the highest $E^\circ$ values (+2.87 V). This means Fluorine is:
questions.explanation: Its high positive potential indicates it has a massive affinity for electrons, making it the strongest common oxidizing agent.

questions.question: Lithium ($Li^+$) has a very negative $E^\circ$ value (-3.05 V). This indicates that:
options: Lithium metal is a very strong reducing agent
Lithium ions are very easy to reduce
Lithium metal is a strong oxidizing agent
questions.explanation: Because $Li^+$ is very hard to reduce (negative $E^\circ$), the reverse reaction ($Li$ metal losing an electron) is extremely favorable.

questions.question: Standard reduction potentials are 'intensive properties.' This means that if you multiply a half-reaction by 2 to balance an equation, the $E^\circ$ value:
questions.explanation: Potential (voltage) is a measure of energy per unit charge. Doubling the amount of substance doesn't change the 'pressure' with which the electrons move.

questions.question: In the EMF series, metals located at the very bottom (most negative potentials) are generally:
questions.explanation: Metals like Potassium and Lithium are at the bottom because they 'hate' being reduced and 'love' being oxidized (losing electrons).

questions.question: Which of the following is true about a substance with a negative reduction potential?
options: It is more difficult to reduce than $H^+$
It is easier to reduce than $H^+$
questions.explanation: A negative value relative to the SHE (0.00 V) means the substance has a lower affinity for electrons than hydrogen ions do.

questions.question: The tendency for a reduction half-reaction to occur is measured in units of:
questions.explanation: Voltage is the unit of electromotive force (potential difference) that drives the flow of electrons.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a great handle on the potential of these reactions.
scoreMessages.70: Well done. You're reading the EMF series correctly!
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: more positive = easier to reduce.
scoreMessages.0: Review the concept of reduction potentials and the reference SHE.
